data.headline: Positioning for Sales-Led SaaS companies | My clients win 2x more, in 3x less time, at 40%+ higher value using my 4-week "Pressure Cooker" program.
data.text:
The 7 important principles to turn a Consulting business into a highly differentiated SaaS company.

That's what I explored in my interview with serial entrepreneur and B2B SaaS Sales expert, JB DaguenÃ© âœŠğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦, CEO Of Evergrowth.

Â 
Here are my highlights:

1 - Start with the hardest thing that's on the table. 

2 - Invest in time and technology to describe your customers' problems better than they can themselves.

3 - Find the tasks for which your customers have the least motivation - and do it for them.

4 - Put your deep knowledge (IP) and AI at work together to create prompts that deliver results nobody can get.

5 - Then build products that don't aim to replace people but instead make them more impactful and human again.

6 - Invest only in those areas where your customers will grow with your solution.

7 - Design all your internal processes around one thing: customer success, from development to marketing to sales to services. 


Curious: Which highlight resonates most with you? 



Ps - The link to the full interview with JB is in the 1st comment

data.text:
Great leadership isn't just about steering the shipâ€”it's about knowing when to adjust the sails and when to let your crew shine. 

Discover these 15 fundamental truths every employer must embrace to cultivate a thriving workplace where everyone feels valued and driven.

1. Don't wait until someone is about to leave to offer them a raise or promotion ğŸƒâ™€ï¸. 
Offer incentives proactively to encourage loyalty and satisfaction.

2. If employees struggle with working from home, it might be more about lacking trust than logistics ğŸ ğŸ’». 
Build trust and provide support for remote work.

3. Often, employees quit their managers, not the job itself ğŸ’”. 
Good leadership is critical for retention.

4. A great workplace culture involves more than just fun extras like comfy seating, free drinks, or apps for meditation ğŸ›‹ï¸ğŸ¥¤ğŸ§˜â™€ï¸. 
It's about values, respect, and employee well-being.

5. Encourage an environment where team members feel safe to say they donâ€™t know something or to voice disagreements ğŸ’¬. 
This openness leads to growth and improvement.

6. Pay employees what they truly deserve, or be prepared for them to move to a competitor who will ğŸ’µ.

7. Regular, constructive feedback helps employees engage more deeply with their work ğŸ‘. 
This can boost morale and productivity.

8. Too much supervision doesn't mean better results; it can actually reduce employees' sense of independence ğŸ¦….

9. Calling a job "entry-level" when it requires significant experience is misleading ğŸ“ğŸ’¼. 
Be honest about job requirements and compensation.

10. Leaders must act according to the values they promote, or they risk losing their team's trust ğŸš«.

11. Sick days or necessary medical appointments should not be deducted from vacation leave ğŸ¥ğŸŒ´. 
Respect employeesâ€™ health needs.

12. Look after your employees well, and they, in turn, will take great care of your customers ğŸ¤.

13. Don't expect new hires to excel immediately without thorough training and a proper welcome to the company ğŸ¯.

14. Ignoring or rewarding poor behavior can destroy a positive workplace culture âŒ. 
Address issues promptly and fairly.

15. It's generally more costly to recruit and train new staff than to adequately pay and keep existing employees ğŸ’°. 
Invest in your people from the start.

data.name: Nikola Velkovski
data.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
data.text:
ğŸ£ Don't Pitch-and-pray. Never, ever.

You are probably familiar with that "famous LinkedIn outreach sequence" of:
- blank connection request
- "Thanks for accepting my connection request!"
- 30s later: *extremely long message where a product/service is pitched, with a calendly link at the end
- each day: *5 unrelated super long follow-ups that try to get you on a call

It works 0% of the time!

Instead:
â€¢ Try to qualify the prospect, try to understand their problem, and see if you can help (selling is about helping & building relationships)
â€¢ Give value first (teach them something, show them a better way, give them valuable information)
â€¢ Treat LinkedIn messages as a chat, not as a "write 1000 words essay"
â€¢ Once you've qualified the prospect, ask them if they want to jump on a call, never do it out of the blue or in the first message

data.name: Nikola Velkovski
data.headline: Co-Founder & CEO @ HeyReach
data.text:
ğŸ¤— Exceptional customer support - the hidden growth hack

Have you noticed that 90% of the reviews on G2, Trustpilot, or any other review sites are about customer support? 

It's the most powerful hidden growth hack, and the root of every successful product I've used. 

We pay great attention to our CS department, and since day 1 - I've always tried to build the company with this mentality. One of the lessons that I've learned building and growing two products, is that the most successful short-term roadmap is always built by your customers. 

ğŸ’¡ CS tips & tricks: 
- Your customer would understand and tolerate "we'll fix it in 3 days, next week, next month, etc.", but won't tolerate getting a late reply. Aim to keep your reply under 15 min, genuinely try to understand their need, and communicate.

And at the end, I must quote one of the best advice about customer support that I've ever received:
- "You can't win just by selling the best product or the best price on the market. You must sell the whole package (product, value, support)." - Manny Medina, at WebSummit.

data.text:
5 simple reasons quiz funnels work wonders for health marketing

In 2017, I left my corporate job to start a marketing agency.

I focused in the nutraceuticals market, and I realised that one thing outperformed everything:

Quiz funnels.

Fast forward to 2024:

I have lost all clients to COVID, I pivoted to exclusively selling quiz funnels and failed.

The reason?

Everyone thinks they can create a quiz. But very few succeed.Â 
This didn't help me in selling my services.

So I pivoted again.Â 

I went back to what I knew best - the healthcare market.

This time is different.
You see, businesses don't just want services, they need tools as well.

And if I make these tools, and tailor them to their needs, I will help them grow more, faster and better - with quiz funnels at the forefront.

But why quiz funnels?Â 

5 reasons:Â 

#1. Better Leads: These quizzes help brands in the healthcare market find people who really want what our healthcare clients offer. It's like finding a needle in a haystack, but way easier.

#2. Way More Interactive Than An Ad: People actually enjoy filling out a quiz that shows them a problem or a solution. They get to talk about what they need, and our clients learn how to help them better.

#3. Smart Answers: From the quizzes, we learn a lot about what people need. This helps us make smarter ads and advice for our clients.

#4. Saves Money: Focusing on quizzes means we don't waste money on stuff that doesn't work. Every dollar goes further now.

#5. We Are the Go-To Guys: Because our experience with quiz funnels goes back to 2017, "everyone" in healthcare marketing wants to work with us now. Our clients are happy, and their customers are even more.

When you use a quiz to find your next healthcare patient, it is like finding a secret sauce that you never, ever want to replace.

How does your clinic deal with new leads?Â  ğŸ¤”

The biggest mistake you can make as a CEO (Iâ€™ve done it myself at lemlist, and Iâ€™ll share how you can fix it):

Rewarding someone from your team who is great at their job by giving them a promotion to management.

The issue is that being a top performer and a top manager are two very different things. 
They require a VERY different skill set.

So how to fix this?

The first step is to understand whether your top performers want to become managers for the money or because they want to lead a team.

If they want to lead a team, you should offer them proper training for that and help them level up.

If they simply want to earn more money, they shouldnâ€™t be managers, and you should allow them to earn more than managers even if they stay individual contributors.

Most people feel like the only â€œway upâ€ is by becoming a manager.

That shouldnâ€™t be the case.

You should offer a path for people to be rewarded for their expertise.

The more value they bring to the company, the higher their paycheck should be.

Hope that helps âœŒï¸

data.name: Lola Bailey
data.headline: Thought Leadership Content for L&D Founders Seeking Freedom, Flexibility, Success. Copywriter & Copy Editor for Global Brands. Book a Call.
data.text:
Founders, if the idea of posting on LinkedIn is intimidating...

First, it is to many people.

Fun fact: most people on LinkedIn don't share content regularly. 

Second, it's less intimidating if you have some sort of structure to guide you.
 
Try this short checklist:

1. What one problem are you solving for your audience?
2. Why do they care about this problem? How does it impact them?
3. What's your unique solution or perspective on the problem?
4. How can you prove your solution works?
5. What's the #1 takeaway/action you want readers to leave with?

A few pro tips:

1. Start with an attention-grabbing hook that highlights the problem. Writing the hook first gives me a sense of direction
2. Structure your post logically with clear, cohesive sections
3. Use stories, examples or visuals to illustrate key points
4. End with a strong call-to-action tied to your main takeaway
5. Keep it concise but impactful 
6. Edit before posting to tighten and polish your writing. Reading aloud might help. Can you reduce the length?

The difference between good and great writing is in the structure and substance. Follow these steps and you'll be well on your way to captivating your audience.

Need help putting it into practice? DM me to find out about my content strategy sessions.

data.headline: Behavioral Sci + Socials â€¢ Ex Cambridge Research Intern â€¢ UChicago dropout â€¢ LSR'23
data.text:
Here's what most don't do when cold emailing (you should do it to maximize your chances of landing that internship/job)

When cold emailing or interviewing with professor with whom youâ€™d like to work in an internship/job capacity, donâ€™t just tell. Instead, demonstrate.

For example, most will write a basic cold email saying that theyâ€™re interested in the professorâ€™s work.

But you, you will show that youâ€™re interested in the professorâ€™s work by suggesting a relevant and sensible hypothetical research project that you wish to conduct with them.

â€œBut how do I come up with research ideas? I know nothing about research.â€

To come up with research ideas, we use this very sophisticated process called thinking. To be specific, critical thinking. 

1ï¸âƒ£ If youâ€™ve ever read a research paper, the way to come up with research ideas can be obvious. 

If itâ€™s not, try reading a paper again (in detail this time) and see if you can figure out how to come up with research ideas. 

Hint: it's a specific section in the paper towards the end ;)

Or to make it easier, you can get my resource that has the source of coming up with research ideas (and my exact cold email + bonus stuff). Feel free to check out the contents at https://lnkd.in/g2Y6Dnnn.

2ï¸âƒ£ Another very simple hypothetical research idea is to conduct the professorâ€™s study in a different context i.e. replicate it.

For example, most social science reseach is based on participants from Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, Democratic (WEIRD) countries. 

We barely have research studying the same phenomenon on Indian participants.

Combine this with the observation that academia incentivizes research that replicates. 

Basically, a paper containing multiple studies showing that a phenomenon exists in two or more countries has a better chance of being published than a paper with just one study (assuming that everything else is the same).

But donâ€™t just blindly suggest to the professor that this phenomenon hasnâ€™t been studied in country X and thatâ€™s why we should study it in country X.

Make your suggestion more compelling. Talk about conditions specific to country X that necessitate the study of that phenomenon here. 

For example, one such condition in India could be the traditional approach towards family: the demand of respect, the obligation, and the interdependence (collectivistic culture).

While most of our generation may not like the Indian traditional approach to family, this approach could be a powerful resource for caregiving, especially for mental illnesses (youâ€™ll find studies supporting this easily if you google them.)

If you want to know more about my approach of applying to research internships, some of my best posts are at https://lnkd.in/dsTJx558 :D
